body:
### Problem

Helpfully since https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27717 neovim  reports fswatch errors. I indeed had one, namely that the numeric format of the latency argument was wrong, this is a feature and not a bug of fswatch as reported here https://github.com/emcrisostomo/fswatch/issues/166. The argument in question is this one: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3c572a31a3bb7009b4ad8eac56da1458acae3b75/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua#L281

In the past I've tried to fix it but somehow my `LC_NUMERIC` is still stuck on `nl_NL.UTF-8` which expects a latency argument of the format `0,5` instead of `0.5`.

An easy fix is to either start nvim with a working locale e.g. `env LC_NUMERIC=en_US.UTF-8 nvim <file>`, another is to add `env = { LC_NUMERIC = 'en_US.UTF-8' },` to the `opts` table of the `vim.system` call:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3c572a31a3bb7009b4ad8eac56da1458acae3b75/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua#L273

I think there's a case to be made for adding the `env` table as it would make this functionality more robust and would prevent a source of confusion, but as you might figure from my locale woes I really wouldn't know what side-effects this would have. Adding the `env` table has worked for me though so far, I believe this local change is what causes the `dirty` in `nvim -v`.

### Steps to reproduce

`env LC_NUMERIC=nl_NL.UTF-8 nvim <file>`

where `<file>` should be some file for which you've got an LSP installed and configured such that fswatch will start.

### Expected behavior

I'd expect no error, but I don't know if this is reasonable as the problem is really on my side because I've got a misconfigured `LC_NUMERIC`.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.10.0-dev-2521+g3c572a31a-dirty

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

OpenSuSE Tumbleweed

### Terminal name/version

konsole 23.08.4

### $TERM environment variable

tmux-256color

### Installation

repo
title: fswatch `--latency` argument is locale dependent
